newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 18.71 pct.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela 6-month TEM yields rise to 18.71 pct.

text.p: Yields on Venezuelan benchmark six-month TEMs rose 182 basis points to 18.71 percent in Tuesday's auction, according to a calculation by Reuters that uses the Central Bank formula.

The Central Bank said it sold 40.00 billion bolivars of 178-day "monetary stabilization", or TEM, bills with a 16.89 percent coupon for a price of 99.18 percent. At last week's auction, the six-month notes yielded 16.89 percent.

The bank also sold 10 billion bolivars of 267-day notes with a 17.24 percent coupon at 97.83 percent and 10 billion bolivars of 351-day notes carrying a 17.58 percent coupon at an average price of 96.53 percent.
Yields for these notes rose 230 basis points to 20.61 percent for the 267-day bills, and 242 basis points to 21.89 percent for the 351-day TEMs.
The weekly TEM bill auctions are the Central Bank's main tool of monetary policy, used to restrict liquidity and establish a benchmark for wider interest rates.
